The more we talk about racism and try to make a big deal out of it, the longer it prospers . Racism isn't the elephant in the room, rather the small crack in the wall. The civil rights moment is over. We're all equal, so let's stop trying to make a fuss ov er nothing and lets start making real connections with people. commentThread.commentText: Honestly I think we would all be better off if we would just give each other the benefit of the doubt.  We are so quick to call each other out for being racist or sexist.  So quick to put down movements (like feminism) and instead of looking at where it originated or the context behind the comment, we go into attack mode.  The truth is most of these comments that are being called "racist" did not come from a place of hate.  Sure the message was poorly conveyed, but that's why we should look to educate people rather than attacking them.  Most people who sa y dumb shit aren't trying to offend, they are just coming from a place of ignorance.  So teach them.  And if someone is letting you know you were wrong, learn from it and grow.

I think it's safe to say that the UK has changed dramatically in the past 25 years. Mass immigration and a ton of speech/behaviour laws since the 1990s have meant that it was inevitable eventually that the races would get along. I think there has been a tipping point in the UK's social progression in recent years also.

- In the past four years, violent crime has fallen by 30% (Crime Survey, more reliable than police recorded figures)
- Teenage pregnancy is the lowest since the 2nd world war.
- The number of people in Young Offenders Institutes has fallen by 55% between 2010-2014.
- The homicide rate has fallen by 48% between 2004-2014.

These are big social changes in a very short period of time. Perhaps in a few decades time, people will look back and recognise this period as one of exceptional social change.

It's not a mindset, it's fact. I'm not saying it's okay to insult white people because of race. But it's definitely not called racism. If you were in Japan, you can't be "racist" towards Japanese people. You can show prejudice through stereotypes, but n ot raci st. Racism is about oppression. A minority can never oppress a majority. So if your group falls under the majority (meaning you have inherent privileges in that country) it's impossible t o be racist towards you and racial rudeness toward your group will never be treated as a serious problem. And i think that's where you're getting confused. When people say that racism towards whites in America is impossible, they're not saying "WHITE PEOPLE DESERVE PUNISHNENT FOR EVERYTHING THEYVE DONE" . It has nothing to do with "white people did slavery and the kkk" or anything like that. People use that as an excuse to be racially prejudice towards white people, but none of it has to do with racism. Racism is solely about privilege and the majority vs. the minority. I'm not saying it's okay to treat people wrong because they're white. I'm just saying it's n ot called racism.

+Lee Allen Lol, oppression means to be subject to unfair treatment and control. You could call a super abusive parent an oppressor. You could never call a poor behaving child an oppressor of their parents. Why? Because the parents are the ones who are in control. No, white people living in South Africa can't be racist towards Africans. You'd be right. Because the area is predominantly African. You can't oppress a majority, you can't oppress an oppressor and you definitely can't oppress a majority group who's (arguably) still an oppressor in your country. Not everything is as simple as a dictionary definition buddy, that's not how the real world works. Maybe you should do some studying yourself, and if you find any sliver time after bashing comments without giving any actual valuable substance to back yourself up, you should consider taking a cultural an d ethnic study class at a college.

+joey clay It's about viewing racism as an institution instead of an action. What you described is racial discrimination. Any time a person treats someone badly or unfairly solely because of skin color, that is racial discrimination. "Racism" is the encompassment of the idea of all these discriminative acts causing a group with significantly less power or control, oppression. Anybody, anywhere can be racially discriminative to anyone. But in order to say a person is encompassing "racism" or bein g "racist", they would have to have the ability to oppress someone with their actions and to essentially add to the overall problem/growing problem of oppression against the group that person falls under. In short, calling a shop owner a "racist" for not allowing Asians in his shop means you are saying that shop owner is fueling the pool of oppression against Asains that already exists. However, if for example an Asian shop owner living in America doesn't allow whites in his shop, that act may be racially discriminative but it is n't "racist" because that man will never have the ability to add to an oppression pool against whites in America. Because white people in America have privilege. All presidents until recent have been white, whites are still the most featured in TV ads, and there hasn't even been racial equality in the country for more even 60 years yet. White people still hold privilege in the country so there is no pool of oppression for them. And that's why society doesn't treat white discrimination as an "active problem" in America. There are thousands of cultural studies courses that will teach you the same thing. The definiti on of racism has immensely evolved over time and it's never going to be as simple as the dictionary definitions everyone wants to use. I'm not making this stuff up.

@GenerateX3 "Because white people in America have privilege" really? all white people are privileged? that's stereotyping. basing your opinion on stereotypes is dumb and risky. your so called "studies" are bullshit. and also i'm talking about white people everywhere, no just the U.S. a black guy bullying a white guy in a white majority country (doesn't matter where) just for the colour of his skin i s racism. that's just one example.
